_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Loving Gas Plant - RMPlan Executive Summary

Facility ID: 100000230911



This executive summary is a brief overview of the Risk Management Plan ("RMP") Program and the associated policies at Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent Holdings LLC's ("The Company") Loving Gas Plant.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are represented in the Emergency Planning and Response Sections of the Loving Gas Plant Process Safety Management ("PSM")/RMP manual. The Company takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at its facilities by ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the safe operation of covered processes and the safe handling of regulated chemicals. As for emergency response, The Company has established and maintained site-specific procedures for emergency notification and response. These procedures will be reviewed with employees on a periodic basis and revised to accommodate changes in staffing when they occur.



The Company understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take measures to prevent accidents that may have an effect on the surrounding community. This understanding is reflected in procedures described and referenced in the PSM/RMP manual. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The Loving Gas Plant Phase II is located in Loving County, near Kermit, Texas.  The facility is a 60 million standard cubic feet ("mmscf")/day natural gas dehydration and liquid hydrocarbon extraction facility that is partially owned and operated by Targa Delaware LLC, a subsidiary of The Company.    



The RMP-regulated substances handled at this facility ar

e flammable mixtures and propane. The flammable mixtures are extracted from the natural gas processed at the plant; while propane is used for refrigeration.  The process includes inlet gas compressors to raise the pressure through the plant, a process skid to extract natural gas liquids, residue compressors to raise the gas pressure from the plant to sales point, a natural gas liquid stabilizer to process any liquids formed in the compression process, and natural gas liquid pumps to push product from the plant to the natural gas liquid sales point.



This facility does not handle regulated toxic substances above their threshold quantities and there are no toxic release scenarios to consider.



Offsite Consequence Analysis Results



Several vessels were evaluated for offsite consequence analyses.  The single worst-case scenario ("WCS") is associated with a release of a flammable mixture at the Loving Gas Plant.  The flammable mixture contains ethane, propane, iso butane, n-butane, iso-pentane, and n-pentane. The scenario is a vapor cloud explosion involving 245,362 pounds of a natural gas liquids ("NGL") contained in the two interconnected NGL storage tanks (TK-893 and TK-894).  The entire inventory of these vessels is assumed to release and ignite, which would impact an area with a 0.5 mile radius. 



The facility is located within a rural area; therefore, the WCS would not affect a public/off-site receptor and is considered a Program 1 process.  A consideration of the 0.5 mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning. Outrigger has numerous controls to prevent such a release and to manage consequences.  Passive mitigation measures include an automated plant shutdown system that can divert the incoming gas to an emergency flare.



Accidental Release Prevention Program for Regulated Substances



The Loving Gas Plant implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program for the purpose of accidental release prevent

ion and employee safety.



Five-Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases from covered processes at the Loving Gas Plant that resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site, or known off site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage during this period. This meets the Program 1 five-year accident history requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations ("CFR") 68.42.



Emergency Response Program



The Loving Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The facility maintains a written emergency response action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The Company has coordinated this emergency response action plan with the Ward County Fire Department.  The emergency response action plan includes procedures for responding to releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of associated fires or explosions. The procedures address the aspects of emergency response, including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies, if a release occurs.  The specific details of the action plan are documented in the PSM/RMP program manual.



Planned Changes for Improved Safety



Ideas for changes to improve safety shall be actively sought from employees. Employee safety meetings that focus on chemical safety issues shall be held regularly at the plant. Employees will be encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards.



Process hazard analyses are conducted with key employees to meet the PSM requirements. During these sessions, recommendations are made for the purpose of improving safety and preventing accidental chemical releases. Each recommendation is considered for implementation. Though not all recommendations may be implemented, all will

be considered.  The exercise has provided the affected employees with a heightened awareness of safety issues related to the covered process.



The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any qualifying change we make to chemicals, technology, equipment, or procedures.



The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of our safety program.



Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that we maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
